title: Expected Free Energy and Policy Selection
description: Mathematical derivation and analysis of expected free energy for policy selection in Active Inference.
learning_objectives: Derive expected free energy from variational principles
Understand the decomposition into epistemic and pragmatic terms
Apply expected free energy to policy evaluation

content.overview: Expected free energy provides a mathematical framework for policy selection in Active Inference. It quantifies the expected cost of pursuing a policy in terms of both goal achievement and information gain.

mathematical_derivation.variational_principle: Minimize expected free energy over policies
mathematical_derivation.expected_free_energy: G(π) = E_Q[ln Q(π) - ln P(o_τ, s_τ)]
mathematical_derivation.interpretation: Softmax policy selection based on negative expected free energy

examples.name: Two-Armed Bandit
examples.solution: Balance between known good arm and uncertain arm

examples.name: Grid World Navigation
examples.solution: Paths that reach goal with minimal uncertainty

optimization_methods.sampling_based: Monte Carlo estimation of expected values

connections_to_decision_theory.expected_utility: Pragmatic term corresponds to expected utility
connections_to_decision_theory.information_economics: Value of information in decision making
connections_to_decision_theory.risk_sensitivity: Different risk attitudes through utility functions

neural_implementation.dopamine_system: Encodes expected free energy and prediction errors
neural_implementation.basal_ganglia: Action selection based on expected free energy

interactive_exercises.description: Calculate expected free energy for simple policies
Optimize policies using expected free energy

common_misconceptions.misconception: Expected free energy is the same as expected reward
common_misconceptions.clarification: Includes both utility and information-seeking components

common_misconceptions.misconception: Lower expected free energy always means better policy
common_misconceptions.clarification: Depends on the specific context and goals
Information seeking must be balanced with goal achievement
